video.title: Python for Everybody - Full University Python Course
video.description:
This Python 3 tutorial course aims to teach everyone the basics of programming computers using Python. The course has no pre-requisites and avoids all but the simplest mathematics. 

🔗 Sample Code Zip: https://www.py4e.com/code3.zip
🔗 Lecture Slides and Handouts: https://www.py4e.com/lectures3/
🔗 Free Textbook: https://www.py4e.com/book.php
🔗 Course Website: https://www.py4e.com/

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Why Program?
⌨️ (0:12:21) Why Program? - Hardware Architecture
⌨️ (0:24:24) Python 3 Windows Installation
⌨️ (0:32:34) Python 3 Mac Installation
⌨️ (0:36:41) Why Program? - Python as a Language
⌨️ (0:44:17) Why Program? - What do we say?

⌨️ (0:56:55) Variables, Expressions, and Statements
⌨️ (1:06:20) Variables, Expressions, and Statements - Expressions

⌨️ (1:26:00) Conditional Execution
⌨️ (1:39:13) Conditional Execution - More Conditional Structures

⌨️ (1:52:48) Functions
⌨️ (2:03:02) Functions - Functions of our own

⌨️ (2:15:21) Loops and Iteration
⌨️ (2:25:04) Loops and Iteration - Definite Loops
⌨️ (2:31:40) Loops and Iteration - Loop Idioms
⌨️ (2:40:07) Loops and Iteration - More Loop Patterns

⌨️ (2:58:39) Strings
⌨️ (3:09:06) Strings - More String Operations

⌨️ (3:27:33) Reading Files
⌨️ (3:35:12) Reading Files - Reading Files in Python

⌨️ (3:48:42) Python Lists
⌨️ (3:59:27) Python Lists - Loop Operations
⌨️ (4:08:52) Python Lists - Strings vs. Lists
⌨️ (4:16:42) Python Lists - Strings, Files, Lists & the Guardian Pattern

⌨️ (4:28:44) Dictionaries
⌨️ (4:36:32) Dictionaries - Counting
⌨️ (4:45:43) Dictionaries - Counting Words in Text
⌨️ (4:58:21) Dictionaries - Counting Word Frequency Using a Dictionary

⌨️ (5:22:46) Tuples
⌨️ (5:32:18) Tuples - Sorting
⌨️ (5:44:26) Tuples - Sorting a Dictionary Using Tuples

⌨️ (5:54:56) Regular Expressions
⌨️ (6:05:21) Regular Expressions - From Matching to Extracting
⌨️ (6:13:47) Regular Expressions - String Parsing

⌨️ (6:22:17) Networked Programs
⌨️ (6:29:45) Networked Programs - Application Protocols
⌨️ (6:38:56) Networked Programs - Write a Web Browser
⌨️ (6:43:10) Networked Programs - Code Example: socket1.py
⌨️ (6:48:58) Networked Programs - Characters and Strings
⌨️ (6:59:57) Networked Programs - urllib
⌨️ (7:05:10) Networked Programs - Code Example: urllib1.py, urlwords.py
⌨️ (7:08:25) Networked Programs - Parsing HTML
⌨️ (7:14:48) Networked Programs - Code Example: urllinks.py

⌨️ (7:23:43) Using Web Services
⌨️ (7:26:35) Using Web Services - XML
⌨️ (7:32:02) Using Web Services - Code Example: xml1.py, xml2.py
⌨️ (7:37:40) Using Web Services - XML Schema
⌨️ (7:51:32) Using Web Services - JavaScipt Notation
⌨️ (7:57:45) Using Web Services - Code Example: json1.py, json2.py
⌨️ (8:03:08) Using Web Services - Service Oriented Approach
⌨️ (8:04:44) Using Web Services - Web Services
⌨️ (8:11:33) Using Web Services - Code Example: geojson.py
⌨️ (8:18:49) Using Web Services - API Security & Rate Limiting
⌨️ (8:28:45) Using Web Services - Code Example: twitter1.py, twitter2.py

⌨️ (8:48:01) Python Objects
⌨️ (8:58:28) Python Objects - Sample Code
⌨️ (9:06:50) Python Objects - Object Lifecycle
⌨️ (9:13:19) Python Objects - Inheritance

⌨️ (9:20:44) Databases
⌨️ (9:35:55) Databases - SQLite Browser
⌨️ (9:45:40) Databases - Code Sample: emaildb.py
⌨️ (9:58:55) Databases - Code Sample: twspider.py
⌨️ (10:08:06) Databases - Database Design
⌨️ (10:16:29) Databases - Representing Relationships
⌨️ (10:20:37) Databases - Relationship Building
⌨️ (10:33:05) Databases - Join Operation
⌨️ (10:43:13) Databases - Code Sample: tracks.py
⌨️ (10:57:45) Databases - Many-to-Many Relationships
⌨️ (11:09:37) Databases - Code Sample: roster.py
⌨️ (11:20:40) Databases - Code Sample: twspider.py

⌨️ (11:20:40) Data Visualization
⌨️ (11:48:18) Data Visualization - Code Sample: Geodata
⌨️ (12:01:05) Data Visualization - Page Rank
⌨️ (12:12:14) Data Visualization - Code Sample: Pagerank Spidering
⌨️ (12:29:12) Data Visualization - Code Sample: Pagerank Computation
⌨️ (12:44:17) Data Visualization - Code Sample: Pagerank Visualization
⌨️ (12:44:17) Data Visualization - Mailing List Crawl
⌨️ (12:57:08) Data Visualization - Code Sample: Gmane Data Retrieval
⌨️ (13:13:42) Data Visualization - Code Sample: Gmane Data Modeling
⌨️ (13:26:04) Data Visualization - Code Sample: Gmane Data Visualization

This course was created by Dr. Charles Severance (a.k.a. Dr. Chuck). He is a Clinical Professor at the University of Michigan School of Information, where he teaches various technology-oriented courses including programming, database design, and Web development.

"Python for Everybody" by Dr. Chuck Severance and the University of Michigan is licensed under CC BY.

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

replies.author: Pipit Gusmayanti
replies.text:
Strings are compared lexicographically using Unicode code points (or ASCII in Python 2).
A - U+0041 (65 in base 10)
Z - U+005A (90 in base 10)
a - U+0061 (97 in base 10)
z - U+007A (122 in base 10)

topLevelComment.author: Firestarterman
topLevelComment.text:
I  used to code in Qbasic and Basic45 in elementary school like a maniac all day every day, it was easy and I loved it.. there was nothing I couldn't make. - In high school I was able to write whole intricate and complicated website templates in HTML, CSS and a bit of PHP. About the same time I learned electronics and soldering and made my own ultrasonic detector in just 2 weeks of learning while I was waiting for my components to arrive.
But ever since then my learning capabilities, patience to learn, remember and and apply any instructions from tutorials went completely blank to the point I cant even have attention to read tutorials unless they are short and have bullet points. I cannot read and remember books anymore.

But I love trying to learn Python because its kinda Simple like Basic although not quite. I would also like to learn Java and Javascrypt and C... but Im getting lost in all the syntax, brackets, nesting and indentations. I realy find it cool looking and ofcourse useful knowledge but I just cant seem to remember it and I quickly loose focus and alertness. It may be because Im working 8 hours a day in logistics and Im coming home tired and going straight to bed. Because I know for a fact that.. when I dodnt have a job.. I could be rested and have focus all night and I was able to follow tutorials and make a calculator in Python and learn al the basics within an hour and finish a project within 4 hours and compile it into an exe and that small achievement would realy make me enthusiastic and proud. (Im 36 now BTW). 

Also I would like to mention that this lesson is extremely easy to follow and easy to learn. The only other I found to be as easy to understand as thos one was from a youtuber DevEd. I would also like to mention that I find it much easier to learn languages (on Duolingo and Drops apps). Like Chinese, Hebrew, Dutch, etc. I can quickly connect the dots and remember like 300 new words per day as a minimum). 

Also at work, I deal with inventory management, picking and packing. Im able to combine a huge amount of codes for using and combining different operations for transfering produce, investigating and solving mistakes, as well as having a superhuman speed of doing  all that, quickly reading numbers and codes on quick moving packages. Remembering thousands of different color codes and clothes styles codes and their corresponding color shades. Multitasking by setting a dozens of different working memories in my mind all at the same time. Which is needed when loading inbound pallets, and cartons with produce and setting them aside or putting them away on shelves, all separated by their delivery numbers, while at the same time keeping in my mind where are they physically located and where do they belong. While at the same time communicating with my coworkers in several different languages. .. Yet Im unable to remember how to type a simple python function.. after years of occasional learning from tutorials and doing some practice projects..... Even though I would love so much to have a knack for coding and to find it easy and to not have discalculia and to be a math genius..... But I guess I will have to give up on it... since I dont have an inspiration or motivation for doing anything with it. To me it only looks cool on the screen and I like developing it here and there for fun when I have the time and energy.... but I guess thats as far as I wille ever go with it.... since it feels like a great relief when I just quit it... but then again every time I see some tutorial I just feel like I have to learn it.

For the same reason I felt I have to pass my driving exam. (And in my country a driving school costs like 500$, lasts 2 to 3 months, and driving exams and lessons are extra. Most of us are passing the theory from the first attempt but driving on on actual roads, practicing and doing exams in the rush hour takes at least 5 to 6 attempts for most people to pass... And only 20% pass. I needed a small fortune, 5 years and 13 attempts to barely pass it. Probably because almost every time I came sleepy to an exam after a night shift... and the day I passed it I came well rested... and then I was waiting a long time for the instructor and I had a time to calm down... and I didnt expect to pass it.. I just took it as a joke and didnt really expect anything..... Until... I stopped the car, the examiner behind me gave me the paper with a signature that I passed.... saying "Here, take it, you passed.. but you know full well how terrible is your driving." .. Al that just so I could have it.... not really to use it.. but more for self confidence. Since Im very scared of driving a car. Not only in Croatia where Im coming from.. where everyone takes good care of other drivers.... but even more here in Netherlands where autistic Dutch and drunk Polish are speeding like crazy, and constantly killing cyclists and being chased by police interceptors.

Anyway... I digress... I guess.. I was really looking for an answer for..... well..... why should I even bother learning to code ? Since I have difficultiers remembering the syntax, I dont see my self using it professionally. I only find it fun.... like, a form of recreation I guess.

replies.author: Pipit Gusmayanti
replies.text:
Python 2's range() returns a list, Python 3's range() returns an iterable object.
To get the same output, do print(list(range(4)))

Finally, I'm done with this beginner tutorial! I finished watching it within 50 days and it took me a lot of time. Because I had to do other things, and the first language that I eagerly learn is Python. I know I haven't understood every element of the knowledge but I will be back here again to absorb things that I missed once I grow more with others! Yes, I'm moving on to the stage of learning Algo/DS (Python-based), The Odin Project(Foundations Course), and Python coding practice. I'm gonna apply to a boot camp in my country, Korea in a couple of months and I need to build more concepts to be a solid programmer in the end. It has been a great journey, Dr. Chuck and I sincerely feel grateful that I've got this great content for beginners like me. I will be back here one day and see how much I've improved compared to now! If you read my comment right now, let's not give up! We can do it and we'll finally make it! Until then, let's grind!  

-2022.08.05 Fri. 🔥

replies.author: Pipit Gusmayanti
replies.text:
The object returned by open() has an "__iter__" and "__next__" method which allows the object to be used in for loop. The return value of "__next__" method is assigned to variable in the for loop on each iteration.

You can read more about this in section 9.8 "Iterators" in The Python Tutorial.

topLevelComment.author: Krzysiekoy
topLevelComment.text:
5:35:37 - sorting a list of tuples by the second element.

Is it only me that feels it is a bit awkard that in order to sort by the second element, we "switch" the keys and values?

So, in the first example from 5:33:20, we want to convert this dictionary: {  "a": 10, "b":  1,  "c": 22  } into a list of tuples: [ ( "a", 10  ), ( "c":  22 ), ( "b", 1 ) ] and sort it. Okay, so we sort by the first element and the sorted result looks like this: [ ( "a", 10  ), ( "b":  1 ), ( "b", 22 ) ].

Okay, and now we get to:  5:35:37 where we want to sort the list of tuples by the second element instead (and by a descending order). So, I would imagine the final result to look like this:

 [ ( "c", 22  ), ( "a",  10 ), ( "b", 1 ) ] but instead we end up with  [ ( 22, "c" ), ( 10,  "a" ), (1,  "b") ] where the things are now flipped on their head.

Am I looking too deep into this? Or am I missing a point? If I am simply asked to sort something based on a particular parameter, why would I flip things around? Wouldn't this cause unnecessary/unexpected side effect?

For example, say we have a a list of items with prices:
Milk, $10
Coffee, $30
PC, $7000

If  ask somebody to sort things in an alphabetical order, I would expect to see the following result,
Coffee, $30
Milk, $10
PC, $7000

And If  ask somebody to sort things by price (descending), I would expect to see the following result,
PC, $7000
Coffee, $30
Milk, $10

I sure wouldn't expect the format of my list to change to:
$7000, PC
$30, Coffee
$10, Milk

just because I'm sorting by price. 🤷‍♂

replies.author: Michael Spencer
replies.text: @Chytruske I did go to university, but not for Computer science.  I recommend reading The Progmatic Programmer, and Clean Coder.  Both of those are great for soft skills in coding.  After this course try to decide what type of programming you want to do, web development, iOS development, data engineering and science.  From there pick more advansed courses in those niches'. Just google "top rated Udemy course for XXXXX" and use that.  Create a Github Repository and store your code projects there then link those projects to your linkedIn.  Took me about 6 months of 2 hours a day to be sufficient enough to get an entry level programming job. I had it easy because I was hired within the company I was already working for.

replies.author: Michael Spencer

1:23:50

inp = input('Europe floor: ')
usf = int(inp) + 1
print('US floor: ' + usf

Don't you have to convert the int to str in order to concat a str to a str? 

For example:

inp = input('Europe floor: ')
usf = int(inp) + 1
print('US floor: ' + str(usf))

topLevelComment.author: B Ntagkas
topLevelComment.text:
this is actually pretty bad teaching, its oldschool and a terrible way to learn. dont tell me the history of things, or how they work in a way that doesnt empower me to achieve my goals. if i wanted to learn to speak english, and you tried to teach me its history, you have failed me, if you try to teach me how nouns work, you have failed me. people dont learn like this, and i guarantee you 2000 years ago(or today for that matter) people didnt learn their first language because they went to school or they knew its history, they just picked it up, and had a goal:to say something important, so they eventually did. like elon musk said, instead of showing me the tools and teaching me all about the nail and the hammer and the tractor, give me instead a goal, something cool i want to achieve, and then show me in an interactive way how to achieve it. and thus, here you need a nail and a hammer, its those 2 things, they are made to be used in this situation right now. teaching works best if i have some goal, something im excited to achieve, something real and tangible, and then you must show me how to get there in a way thats cool and memorable. this old way of teaching is really really now good for humans to learn. just saying: i want to learn python because: i want to work/make money/i want to learn to code, its not real and tangible and short term enough.
its better than nothing but it doesnt take a genius to see what real good teaching is like. oh wait...i guess maybe it does take a genius after all.

replies.author: Abhay Agarwal
replies.text:
python isn't a magical language . Follow rules and it will work fine . There is something called formatting of strings in python . For example, 

print(f"{Character_name} is 20 years old") 

or you can do this way, 

print(Character_name , " is 20 years old) 

In your code "+ character_name+" is simply a string .

I accelerated the video a little bit but learned new things almost from the beginning! Right now for example ( 2:53:18 ), I just learned how to use the variable None and I'm blown away! I've been doing loops wrong for months! 😂 Thank you Prof!

topLevelComment.author: Orange County DelGuy
topLevelComment.text:
In chapter 5 More loop patterns, the for loop uses a list to determine the number of iterations as follows:
for value in [9,41,12,3,74,15];
which makes it 5 iterations.

What if I need to run it 200 times?  Would I have to write a list from 1 to 200?  Would it be: for value in [1, 2, 3...  and so on until... 198, 199, 200]?  That's a lot of numbers to have to type.

How could I write a simple: for x=1 to 200?  Of course I borrowed that from a different language, but I did it just to ask this question.

Now, I know I can use a While Loop and Start at 1 and increment the iteration variable by one in each loop, but my question is:  Is there a way using the for loop?

replies.author: Retvolki
replies.text:
No doubt using a for loop is the most elegant way to do it so good job figuring it out!
Also, you could possibly loop through the list combining a while loop with an if statement, but that's a solution that would require to write a bit more code so it's less efficient.
However, for educational purposes feel free to also try something like this:

a = [1, 544, 484, 789]; b = 0
while len(a) > b:
  c = a[b]; b += 1
  if c % 2 == 0: print(c)

Or like this if you wanna display the possible answers in a more user friendly way:

a = [1, 544, 484, 789]; b = 0; d = []
while len(a) > b: 
  c = a[b]; b += 1
  if c % 2 == 0: d += [c]

print (f"List of all divisible numbers: {d}")

I hope it helps!

replies.author: Retvolki
replies.text:
It is very simple, original file loops twice (nested for loop) because files have lines and words in ea line. When instead of using a file you decided to hardcode one big string, you should fix that as well since you no longer need to loop through lines, just words! That makes the code even simpler.

Something like this should work: 

name = "Big string of your choice"

counts = dict()
words=name.split()
for word in words:
    counts[word]=counts.get(word,0)+1
bigword= None
bigcount=None
for word,count in counts.items():
    if bigcount is None or count>bigcount:
        bigword=word
        bigcount=count
print(bigword,bigcount)

I hope it helps!!

topLevelComment.text:
Thank you so much for the wonderful tutorial! By the way, I think for 3:47:00 when we deal with bad file names, the code can be improved as follows: 
##
file_name = input('Enter the file name: ')

try:
    file_handle = open(file_name)
    count = 0
    for line in file_handle:
        if line.startswith("Subject:"):
            count = count + 1
    print("There are",count, "subjects in",file_name)
    
except:
    print("file name does not exist:", file_name)
##
This way python would always run the except message as long as no available file name is found. quit() doesn't work well in some circumstances I'm afraid.

topLevelComment.text:
3) (LISTAS) Objetivo: Criar listas de tamanhos definidos e manipular elementos indexados
Elaborar um programa em Python que armazene numa lista (identificada com o nome de um dos integrantes 
do grupo) os termos de uma progressão aritmética definida da seguinte forma: a quantidade de termos é dada 
pela soma dos três últimos dígitos da matrícula desse aluno (por exemplo, 157 => 1+5+7 = 13 termos), o 
primeiro termo é dado pelo último dígito da sua matrícula desse mesmo aluno (no nosso exemplo, o primeiro 
termo é 7) e a razão será digitada através do teclado, sendo que o número deve ser positivo, ímpar, maior que 
2 e menor que 8 (o programa deve testar/validar essa entrada). No final do preenchimento da lista, imprimir 
o nome e matrícula desse aluno numa linha, na linha seguinte a quantidade de elementos acima da média 
(que só pode ser calculada após todos os elementos serem digitados na lista) e todos os elementos dessa lista
em outra linha (todos na mesma linha separados por vírgula). Me ajudar!!!

topLevelComment.author: Martin S.
topLevelComment.text:
Programming is a mindset... a mindset of transferring thoughts of creativity onto a screen in the form of code, telling a computer how it can realise your thoughts and creativity in a way that makes sense and is useful---to yourself and to others using your creative designs to create even more great designs.

Once you've learned to adopt that mind, code becomes as trivial as a knife and fork: not all utensils feel good in your hands, some work better than others for different tasks(Stake Knives vs regular fork and knife); some languages are better suited at different tasks than others, but are ultimately capable of bringing to life creativity of their own.

replies.author: Moneybagg Mario
replies.text:
@Fr0s7y. I'm not sure if I understand your question correctly or not but atom is just a text editor to write and save files to actually run the code you have to open the .py file via the cmd prompt or open idle and run it in the interpreter that way. 

Of course if you run the code via the cmd prompt you will have to navigate to the directory of the .py file and call the file by name at the prompt.

You can also open the python interpreter in the cmd prompt and use the interpreter to write code and test it live. 

Atom is just a text editor though not an interpreter. The magic of atom is being able to write code in a bunch of different languages without having to switch applications all you have to do is save the file under the right extension its like a swiss army knife for programmers.

topLevelComment.author: Akshata Kanumuri
topLevelComment.text:
Anyone trying to run if conditional statement as shown 51:29 mins if you are not getting result as expected use "elif" instead of the second "if"  Something like this:
 x = 5
if x < 10:
    print('Smaller')
elif x < 20:
    print('Bigger')
    
print('Finish') 
Then you will get the expected output: 
Smaller
Finish

topLevelComment.author: Sarvesh Parakh
topLevelComment.text:
So this course is really amazing. Its been 2 days since I started the course. Maybe 3. Depends how you count them.

In these 2-3 days:

1. I made my own betting game where you bet on a dice rolling by choosing a number of your choice. Computer rolls a dice and shows you the number on its surface. You win money if you win your bet (i.e. the number you  chose is equal to the number on the face of the dice) or loose money if you loose your bet. This program continues to run and ask for more bets until the user chooses to exit. Today I updated the program so that it starts with a set amount of money in a users account (using a username variable). Then he can choose to bet any amount from that set amount of money. If he wins, his bet amount is doubled and added back to his total amount. If he looses, his bet amount is deducted from his total amount. If he keeps loosing and his total amount hits 0, a message pops up saying ‘you have no more money to bet. Please run the program again under a different username to get free coins to play the game again.’ Of course, when you exit and run the program again, even if you use the same username you used last time, your account starts with a full balance. I will fix this soon so that different users can have different balances. Even after exiting the program, when they restart, their balances are the same as when they exit. I just don’t know how to do this yet because I’m only 3 hours and 30 something minutes in the video. (This all only happens in the terminal. There are no graphics or a fancy app. I don’t know how to do that yet because this is my first course in python and I’m not at that point in the course yet (if that point even exists in this course). I made this using while loops, and if else statements.
2. I made a calculator that can do addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, percentage, percentage multiplication (eg. 30x80% = 24), squares, cubes, and square roots. The key thing is, it doesn’t exit unless the user wants. Meaning, you can do infinite operations. Say you wanted to do 6+7*8+sqr89-34%*56+sq34 or if you wanted to do a simple one like 4*5+6, you could do both. I made this entire code using while loops, a math function which is only imported when user wants to square root a number (The formula for square root without a math function is quit complicated and I don’t yet know how to make it work in python), try and except function for % and else statements for exit whenever the user wants.
3. I made a program that tells you what day of the week it was for any date you choose. I did this using if else. I was practicing if else. So i wrote 200+ lines of if else to tell accurately what day it was for any date from year 1900 to year 2019. I created a updated version just after finishing the one mentioned above. This new version only has about 100 lines of code and it tells you any day for any date from year 1700 to year 2399.
4. I also made a lot of less impressive things like a 10 questions quiz that counts your total score and ranks you as grade A, B, C, D, or F based on your score out of 10. I’m thinking of adding a betting function in it just to make it more interesting. I also want to add a time limit for a question to be answer, else the answer is considered wrong and the score for that question is counted as 0. However, I don’t know how to add time limits yet.

So My point is, this course is really wonderful. I’m just in about 3 and a half hour and I could do so much. Not saying m smart or anything. M just a average guy. But this Dr. Trucker teaches so well. I hope everyone is making amazing stuff. If you wish to study codes together, you can also comment below and maybe we can study python together. I’ve coded for over 12-14 hours daily that is why I could make this much in 2-3 days. Currently, I’m addicted to coding lol.
Hit me up in the comments below if you wanna access and study any of my codes mentioned above. Maybe I can study yours?

topLevelComment.author: Sheikh Abdullah
topLevelComment.text:
# NUMBER GUESSING GAME:
n = 55
                               # SET YOUR SECRET NUMBER HERE.

turns=0

while turns != 9:

    Guess = int(input("Input a number: "))

    if Guess > n:

        turns += 1

        print(f"Your no. is greater.\nTurns left: {9-turns} ")

        if turns == 9:

            print('Game Over!')

            break

    elif Guess < n:

        turns += 1

        print(f"Your no. is shorter.\nTurns left: {9-turns} ")

        if turns == 9:

            print("GAME OVER!")

            break

    else:

        print(f"You GUESSED in {turns+1} turn/s")

topLevelComment.author: Philip Schroeder
topLevelComment.text:
Good effort, though I am not sure, everybody could do it. My mom would certainly not understand it, and I remember from school quite a few people who had a problem in math understanding that when you have x in an equation and you have x somewhere else with a value, you can exchange the x in the equation with the value of x. The tutorial had in my opinion the same fault that I see in many approaches, and really good approaches.
After a while the instructor feels that he has done enough of the slow introduction and puts in words that they are familiar with but the audience is not.
I am pretty sure when looking at the word counting program, my mom would ask "what's a histogram", and instead of forgetting about it because it is not important atm she would give up because she couldn't understand everything and then would conclude that she doesn't understand anything. 
For instance your introduction of the vonNeumann-computer started off quite comprehensive, but if I were my mom, you would have lost me between memory and hard drive. In your place I would have probably said something like 

"The CPU is not as fast in reading instructions as you are in providing them so you put the instructions into a bowl called main memory where the CPU can take them from later when it has the time. But when you turn off the computer because you don't want to bother with computers today anymore, the computer is cleaning the dishes and the stuff in your bowl gets thrown away. So if you want to use it again when you turn on the computer next time, then you have to store it in some preserving jar which in case of the computer is called hard drive."

 I watched the video for quite some time, and for instance after installing python, you said that you like to use the command line without telling what a command line is and why we need it at all. Again my mom would be overwhelmed with questions in her head and shut down.

I really liked the video, for me as a computer scientist it seemed quite easy to understand, on a level that I would assume everybody could understand if it weren't for my experience that people not affine to computers have much more basic problems in understanding than I would imagine.

So to conclude, your approach is a very good one, you put in a lot of patience and the level of assumption of prior knowledge of the audience was quite low, but I am not confident that everybody could understand it.

topLevelComment.author: Bartosz Mroczkowski
topLevelComment.text:
If I type the code as it is above 
word = "banana"
count = 0
for letter in word:
    if letter == "a":
        count = count + 1
print(count)
Python will count letter "a" and it will show 3
But if I type the code:
word = ["banana", "apple"]
count = 0
for letter in word:
    if letter == "a":
        count = count + 1
print(count)
it will show 0
Why?

replies.author: AHMED ELHADY
replies.text: Cuz Word ["Banana", 'Apple'] are known for a (list), so the first item is 'Banana' not 'a' and the second item is 'apple', If you wanna do that, you could use (Nested Loops) to iterate over the chars of the items(banana or apple).

replies.author: onimaru0612
replies.text:
@Aris Totle object-oriented programming (OOP) is something different than just normal coding. It provides more tidy code, easier to maintain. Of course it will be harder to read and fully understand, just like when you fold up your clothes instead of leave it messy, it will be harder to find and wear exactly what you want. But with larger scale, you must keep everything in an order for the love of God.
Functional programming (FP), in other hand, it will be so easy to read, so clear that it looks like human language. But you can not rely on something that much messy when you have to control lots and lots of functions, works. Even if you can, you shouldn't.

import socket

mysock = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_STREAM)
mysock.connect(('data.pr4e.org', 80))
cmd = 'GET http://data.pr4e.org/romeo.txt HTTP/1.0\n\n'.encode()
mysock.send(cmd)

while True:
    data = mysock.recv(512)
    if (len(data) < 1):
        break
    print(data.decode())
mysock.close()

replies.author: Juan López
replies.text: @Milan Tomin The content is the same, although he re-recorded the lectures for Coursera, so you will see a different background setting in the Coursera videos.  Note that on the py4e website and in Coursera, the lectures are in separate videos.  Basically, what freeCodeCamp.org did was put all of the videos together in a single "giant" video.  However, in the py4e website Dr. Chuck has an assignment for most lectures (the same assignments as in the Coursea course, for the most part), so you might want to give the site a try.
